ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MALE SINGAPOREANS MARRYING NON-SINGAPORE CITIZENS
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Labour (a) how many male Singaporeans have applied for approval to contract marriage with non-Singapore citizens up to 28th February, 1977 have been approved; (c) what are the reasons for rejecting applications; (d) how many applications have been approved subject to the contracting parties accepting sterilization after the birth of the second child; and (e) whether he is satisfied with this policy.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, in answer to questions (a) to (e):

    (a) Up to 28th February this year, there were 5,968 marriage applications from male Singaporeans;

    (b) Of these, 4,649 applications have been approved;

    (c) 1,319 applications were rejected because the work permit holder did not meet policy requirements, i.e. working in Singapore for less than five years where the work permit holder was an unskilled worker;

    (d) So far 1,107 marriage cases have been approved under the sterilisation scheme, i.e, where the contracting parties have accepted sterilisation on the birth of the second child;

    (e) The Ministry is satisfied with the work permit marriage policy. The policy is being monitored closely, and if developments warrant changes, such changes will be made.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, can the Minister of State inform this House whether it is true to say that there has been a change in the policy requiring both contracting parties to be sterilised? Why both?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, there has been no change in the sterilisation scheme when it

was first started right up to now. I think my Minister had explained the other day in this House why both parties had to be sterilised, rather than one party. I do not think I need to repeat.

PULAU UBIN AND PULAU TEKONG
(Provision of water and electricity)


    2. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development and Communications what steps have been taken to provide the islanders in Pulau Ubin and Pulau Tekong with water and electricity.

    The Minister for National Development and Communications (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Utilities Board has started work on what is known as the Pulau Tekong Reservoir Scheme. This calls for the construction of an impounding reservoir with a storage capacity of 1.4 million cubic metres and a water treatment plant of 6,800 cubic metres/day capacity on the island. When this $6.23 million project is completed in 1979, piped water supply will be available on the island.

    The Public Utilities Board undertook a survey which shows that providing piped water to Pulau Ubin would be uneconomical. It would also be uneconomical to provide island-wide electricity to both Pulau Ubin and Pulau Tekong as the houses on these islands are scattered and the expected demand too low to justify the cost of installation of electrical distribution equipment. The Urban and Rural Services Committee concurred with these findings and informed the Board that no action need be taken until more information on the development of these islands is available.

VACANT STALLS IN HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD MARKETS AND HAWKER CENTRES


    4. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether he is aware that many stalls in Housing and Development Board markets and hawker centres are vacant and if he will request the Board to relax or revise the existing policy so that those vacant stalls may be taken up.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Sir, I am aware of the vacant stalls in the HDB markets and hawker centres. However, on the recommendation of the Hawkers Co-ordinating and Licensing Committee, these stalls are reserved for the resiting of about 11,750 licensed street hawkers.

    Under the present set of criteria, stalls are awarded to deserving cases such as licensed hawkers and small-time traders affected by clearance, licensed street hawkers and genuine hardship cases. The criteria are under constant review and are revised whenever necessary and justifiable.

PEDESTRIAN OVERHEAD BRIDGE ACROSS MARSILING DRIVE


    5. Mr Lee Yiok Seng asked the Minister for National Development and Communications if it is proposed to construct an overhead bridge across Marsiling Drive in

Column: 1326

front of Block 2 and Block 10, Woodlands New Town, to provide for safe crossing of the road in view of the several accidents which have occurred there.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, Marsiling Drive is a two-way undivided road within the Woodlands New Town. Site investigations have shown that at present pedestrians are crossing mostly in front of Block 2 and Block 10. However, a traffic count at the site on 15th March, 1977 revealed that vehicular traffic volume along Marsiling Road was very low with only 236 vehicles per hour against 192 pedestrians per hour. In view of the low traffic and pedestrian volume, there is no immediate need for an overhead pedestrian bridge.

    The present situation, however, will be kept in constant review.

WOODLANDS NEW TOWN
(Extension of bus services)


    6. Mr Lee Yiok Seng asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether it is possible to extend the bus services into Woodlands New Town. such as routing the buses from New Admiralty Road into Marsiling Drive. Marsiling Road and Marsiling Lane instead of routing them direct to the bus bay at New Admiralty Road as at present.

    The Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, Woodlands New Town is presently served by four SBS services which terminate at the bus terminal along Admiralty Road, between Marsiling Lane and Marsiling Drive. The flats which are now occupied are situated within a quarter mile or 400-metre radius from the bus terminal and are within walking distance from two pairs of bus stops from Admiralty Road. In view of the close proximity of the existing terminal and bus stops to the flats, it is unnecessary for the SBS to re-route its

Column: 1327

buses from New Admiralty Road into Marsiling Drive. Marsiling Road and Marsiling Lane for the time being.

    When the New Town is nearing completion, the SBS will introduce internal bus services. Under this system, a comprehensive network of internal services will bring residents from various neighbourhoods to the proposed town centre terminal where external services will originate. This will not only provide commuters a better level of service but it will also save considerable journey time and operating costs. The SBS is presently working closely with the HDB on the design of the proposed town centre terminal which is expected to be operational in about 24 months' time.

KIM CHUAN VILLAGE COMMUNITY CENTRE


    7. Mr Tan Cheng San asked the Minister for Culture and Science and Technology whether and when the Kim Chuan Village Community Centre will be rebuilt by the People's Association.

    The Minister for Culture and Science and Technology (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Kim Chuan Village community centre referred to by the hon. Member for Paya Lebar was demolished in late December 1976 to make way for development by the Roads and Sewerage Department. Such development has resulted in the rapid resettlement of the residents from the area. Replacement for this centre is considered unnecessary as the remaining population is small and can well be served by the Lorong Tai Seng community centre about 1.6 km away.

    The hon. Member may wish to know that the People's Association is in constant touch with the relevant authorities on future housing development plans affecting the constituency. If future population growth in Paya Lebar constituency warrants it, the provision of another centre will be favourably considered.

WOMEN'S CHARTER
(Waiting period for divorce)


    8. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Social Affairs if he will consider introducing legislation to amend Section 82 of the Women's Charter to allow couples to take divorce proceedings after a separation period of three years instead of seven years as provided in the law.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng) (for the Minister for Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the proposal to reduce the waiting period for divorce is controversial, and the rising divorce rate clearly indicates that we need to be circumspect before introducing amendments to the Women's Charter to permit divorce on the ground that the parties have lived separately for any period shorter than the present period of seven years. Over the last five years, the rate of divorce has more than doubled - from 304 cases in 1972 to 803 in 1976. Although the figures for divorces are low when compared with the total number of marriages, nevertheless they indicate an unhealthy trend. We will have to continue to monitor the situation before considering a reduction of the period during which the parties have lived apart as a ground for divorce.

    Ever since it became publicly known that my Ministry appointed a Committee to review the Women's Charter. the press and some individuals have been speculating on the changes that would be made in our divorce laws. Some well-meaning, but obviously not really down-to-earth, suggestions have been made regarding the waiting period for divorce. Strangely, a proposal was made by some women's organisations to amend the law to permit divorce to be granted on the ground that the parties have been living separately for a period of only one year. Mr Speaker, Sir, as you are aware, the Women's Charter permits a divorce to be granted where the parties have been living separately for a period of not less than seven years and reconciliation is unlikely. At a time when we should

Column: 1329

strengthen the family unit, will it help to make divorce easier?

    In some countries where the laws have been changed to make divorce easier, the rate of divorce has multiplied. In certain western countries where divorce can be obtained easily, marriages appear to have lost their sanctity, but it is the children of such marriages who always suffer. A united family gives strength to our social fabric and a marriage must therefore be regarded as an institution to be cherished and preserved. For this reason, we cannot afford to make changes in our marriage and divorce laws without careful deliberation. If after thorough investigation we find amendments can be made which will ease irreconcilable couples in getting divorces earlier but without weakening either the family unit or the institution of marriage, we shall do so.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, by insisting that the separated couple should wait for a period of seven years, are we not encouraging immorality because we cannot expect a man and a woman to remain angelic for seven years?

    Mr Speaker: What is your supplementary question, Mr Ho?

    Mr Ho See Beng: Is the Senior Parliamentary Secretary not encouraging immorality by insisting on a seven-year period?

    Mr Chan Chee Song: Sir, the Member for Khe Bong said that when a married couple live separately, he or she might indulge in immorality. Is he implying that all men and women in Singapore likewise do? Even if this immorality were existent, I do not think it deserves a reduction of the seven-year period.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Song): Sir, is there any indication to show that a seven-year period is a necessary deterrent against divorce than, say, a three-year waiting period?

Column: 1330



    Mr Chan Chee Seng: In my answer I have said that we are monitoring these cases. If this does not seem a very reasonable period, we will reconsider the case.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, does the Senior Parliamentary Secretary agree that a seven-year period is too long?

    Mr Chan Chee Song: At the moment, no, Sir.

WOMEN'S CHARTER
(Court order of maintenance/alimony)


    9. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Social Affairs if he will consider introducing legislation to amend the Women's Charter so that no order of maintenance or alimony will be made by the court if the husband commits no matrimonial offence and the divorce is on the ground of seven years' separation.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng (for the Minister for Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, when any decree absolute for divorce is made by a Court, the Court has power to make, if it thinks fit, an order that the husband pays to the wife a gross sum of money or an annual sum for any term not exceeding her life. In making such an order of alimony, the Court wilt have regard to the wife's property, if any, to the ability of the husband and to the conduct of the parties. The Court also has power to make an order, if it thinks fit, on the husband for payment to the wife during their joint lives of such monthly sum for her maintenance and support as the Court thinks reasonable. The order for maintenance may be either in addition to or instead of an order of alimony. In making an order of maintenance or alimony, the Court is guided by equitable principles. In general, a Court does not make an order in favour of a guilty wife who is responsible for the break-up of the marriage.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the application by a wife, upon divorce, for the payment of alimony or maintenance is decided according to the merits of each individual case. The hon. Member for Khe Bong is suggesting that the

Column: 1331

law be changed so that we take away the jurisdiction of the Court to grant alimony or maintenance simply because the parties are divorced on the ground that they had been living apart for a period of seven years and the husband had committed no matrimonial offence. The law, as it stands, enables the Court to exercise its discretion after examining the circumstances of each case, and it is undesirable to amend the law to introduce such an inflexible rule.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, if the husband had not committed any matrimonial offence during the seven years that both parties were separated, why should the husband pay alimony to the wife on a decree of divorce?

    Mr Chan Chee Song: Sir, the Court will decide on that.

JALAN CHENG HWA AND MANDAI ROAD, 20 KMS
(Provision of markets)


    10. Mr Lee Yiok Seng asked the Minister for Law and the Environment whether there are any plans to construct (i) a new market at Jalan Cheng Hwa to replace the present old market; and (ii) a market at Mandai Road 20 kms to cater for the needs of the residents in that area.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Chor Yeok Eng) (for the Minister for Law and the Environment)(In Mandarin): Sir, my Ministry has no plans to build a market at Jalan Cheng Hwa. However, a proposal is still under study for a market-cum-food centre, off Lorong Malai, to replace the old market at Jalan Cheng Hwa and to resite the street hawkers in the area.

    There is no plan to build a market at Mandai Road, 20 kms, as the population is small and scattered.

NON-PENSIONABLE ANNUAL ALLOWANCE
(Payment to retiring officers)


    11. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Finance (a) how many Civil

Column: 1332

Servants retired on reaching the age limit in each of the years 1973 to 1976; and (b) how many of them did not receive the non-pensionable annual allowance, either in whole or in part, in the year of their retirement.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Sir; the numbers of civil servants who retired on reaching the age limit are:- 
                           



                      1973 - 505

                      1974 - 340

                      1975 - 217

                      1976 - 326


    The non-pensionable annual allowance is payable only to officers who are in service as on 31st December and therefore those who leave the service in the course of the year, on account of resignation or retirement, are not eligible for the allowance.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Sir, I wish to ask the Minister if he will consider removing the existing stipulation not to extend the payment of the 13th month annual wage supplement to civil servants who retire before the 31st of December or to their dependants if they die during service, even if the quantum of payment is proportionate to the number of months they have served.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I am not quite sure I understand the gist of the Member's question. The present position is that all serving officers on the 31st December get the allowance, and all officers who are not serving on the 31st December do not get the allowance. Under the present system there is no question of any one being entitled to any proportionate payment.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong: Sir, I am aware of that provision. That is why I am asking the Minister whether he will consider removing that stipulation. I am aware that there is a stipulation at present barring these people from enjoying the benefit. My question is, will he consider removing this stipulation?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: The answer is no. The allowance is not a bonus. I think I must stress this. It is not payable like, say, bonuses, in

Column: 1333

companies where maybe a proportionate amount can be paid, because it is for services rendered during the year. The intention of the non-pensionable - annual allowance is to reward officers who are still with us on 31st December and who will continue in service with us for the rest of the year, and to give their loyal service to the Government.

    Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, what about those officers who retire on the 30th December, subjected to one day's break in service on the 31st December, and re-engaged on the 2nd January?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: The answer is simply no. It does not fall within the definition. But the terms of re-employment are such that they can be renegotiated to include whatever may be necessary - a higher salary or a lower salary; or a salary to include consideration for whatever he may have lost.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong: Sir, does the Minister not agree that the 13th month annual wage supplement is a form of deferred monthly wages, as he has stated in Parliament when this was announced? If so, should not the civil servant who retires or dies while in service be entitled to at least part payment of the 13th month annual wage supplement?

    I would like to also ask the Minister if it is not true that civil servants who have just joined the civil service are entitled to a proportionate amount of the 13th month payment in the first year. If so, is it not only fair and equitable that the same entitlement be extended to retiring civil servants in their last year of service, or to their dependants should they die while in service?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: The answer is no. It may be that there should be a pensionable allowance based in the manner in which the Member suggests, but we did not frame it in that manner, and therefore there is no entitlement. I do not think we would be prepared to change the nature of this concept of annual non-pensionable allowance to the nature suggested by the Member concerned.

In fact, the first idea was that this would be in the form of a wage increase except that, instead of giving it in 12 instalments for the year, we suggested that it may be desirable to give it in one lump sum payment, and therefore the first annual allowance was given to officers serving on the 31st March. Members may note that it was not intended that it should be for service for the calendar year. The first payment was made on 31st March and subsequently we thought that perhaps the end of the year would be a more desirable time to pay because that is the time where there are festivals - the Christmas and the Chinese New Year.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong: The Minister has, in fact, confirmed what I said, but my question has not been answered. As he has agreed with me that this 13th month payment is actually a form of deferred monthly wages -

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: I did not say that.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong: Well, he said that it should be a wage increase and that it should be paid at the end of the year instead of monthly. That is a deferred monthly wage increase to be paid at the end of the year. My question earlier was, if this was so, then if someone has served seven months in the year, he should be entitled to seven months of that wage increase. That is my question. Sir, unless the Minister said otherwise.

    Mr Speaker: I am not sure whether you are asking questions or making a speech. Mr Sia.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, my question is simply this. If a person has worked for 20 years and, just short of a few days before he qualifies for it, he should kick the bucket, should we not be more humane and sympathetic and pay pro rata to his dependants?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, that is another question. If he suggests that some gratuity, pension, or other allowance should be given, let us consider it on that basis, and not make the non-pensionable allowance which is not intended to be a gratuity, a pension or an exgratia payment to him under those terms.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): In the light of the Minister's reply, would he consider favourably the question of the Member for Jalan Kayu by enlightening this House further on this aspect?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I am not in a position now to discuss a revision of the whole Pension Ordinance or the CPF or the gratuity or ex-gratia payment.     Resumption of Debate on Question (18th March, 1977).

    `That the sum to be allocated for Head W be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BAA 1101.' - (Mr S. Dhanabalan).

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Ho See Beng(In Mandarin): Sir, in this Debate on the Budget estimates for the Ministry of Education, I wish to point out the remarkable success of the bilingual education policy implemented by the Ministry of Education. This remarkable success is evident to everyone at home and abroad. The successful effort of the Ministry of Education in this respect should be recognised and widely acclaimed by us.

    However, I now wish to bring up a problem, also a fact, which is right before us. This concerns the successful candidates in the Government Secondary IV examination for the Chinese stream, who have entered

Column: 1336

Pre-U I classes. It was not until the 9th of March that the Ministry of Education released the list of successful candidates to the various schools. The successful students then reported at their respective schools on the 10th of March. They attended classes on 11th of March, but found that the first school term ended the following day, the 12th of March. They have paid a month's school fees for only one day's tuition. What is the rationale behind all this?

    The Government Secondary IV examination for the Chinese stream was held in mid-November last year and the results were released on 5th February this year. The results, unlike in previous years, were not published in the press and the candidates concerned had to return to their respective schools to check their results. The successful students were required to return to their respective schools on 7th, 8th and 9th February to fill up the relevant application forms for admission to the schools of their choice. These forms had to be submitted by the various schools to the Ministry of Education for processing.

    The processing is said to be done by computers and as such, in our mind, it must be time-saving, highly efficient and fast, and the newly admitted Pre-U I students should have been able to begin classes seven or ten days later. But, alas, they have to wait until two days before the end of the first term to start their first lesson. Just how much, may I ask, can they learn in the circumstances? What kind of education are we promoting?

    The questions I wish to ask are firstly, the results of the Government Secondary IV examination for the Chinese stream were released on 5th February and completed application forms (for admission to Pre-U I) were all submitted to the Ministry for computerised processing on 9th February. But the Ministry of Education had to drag on until 9th March to release the lists of the newly admitted Pre-U I students to the various schools. What is the cause for such a long delay?

    Secondly, does the Education Ministry know that much precious time of the

Column: 1337

students had been wasted? Or was there anything wrong with the Ministry's administration in dealing with this matter?

    Thirdly, is it not a fact that the way the matter was handled had caused much precious time of the students to be wasted? Pre-U I teachers in many schools had no classes to teach. Is this not a waste of the taxpayers' hard-earned money? Singapore's population is just over two million people, and with so many people being employed by the Education Ministry yet the Ministry is so inefficient in its work. If the Education departments in countries like China and the United States, with large populations, were to follow our Education Ministry, then it would not be difficult to imagine how many people would have to be employed. However, the efficiency and the performance of the Education departments in these countries are not difficult to see.

    Educating the young is a long term process and an arduous task. It is the mainstay of State policy, with politics, national defence, social and economic development and communications as its ramifications. In the early 1960s Western sociologists discovered, after much study and research, that education is the motivating force of national progress. The long delay by our Ministry of Education in handling the admission of Pre-U I students not only runs counter to the guiding principle of education but it also makes the Ministry guilty of dereliction. I hope that all Members of the House will take note of this. I also hope that the Education Ministry will pay attention to the work of students by exercising greater supervision over its staff, tightening its administration and raising efficiency.

    Encik Sidek Bin Saniff (Kolam Ayer): Sir, one of the most important instruments of national endeavour for the progress of a country is education.
